chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: First episode
chapter.summary: Covers the assessment and management in primary care of a first episode of primary genital herpes.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I treat genital herpes?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Oral antivirals are the primary treatment for genital herpes simplex infection — treatment should commence within 5 days of the start of the episode, or while new lesions are forming for people with a first clinical episode of genital herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • Prescribe oral aciclovir 400 mg three times a day for 5–10 days, or 200 mg five times a day for 5–10 days, or alternatively:
    • Valaciclovir 500 mg orally twice a day for 5–10 days.
    • Famciclovir 250 mg orally three times a day for 5–10 days.
  • Advise all people about appropriate self care measures to help relieve symptoms.
  • Topical antiviral drugs are not recommended, as they offer minimal clinical benefit.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Treatment of genital herpes simplex virus [WHO, 2016], the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015], and a systematic review Genital herpes: oral antiviral treatments [Hollier 2013].

Dose of antivirals and duration of treatment
  • Be aware that dose recommendations for antivirals and the duration of treatment may differ between guidelines for treatment of genital herpes, the Summary of Product Characteristics and the British National Formulary (BNF). 
    • BASHH recommends five days of antiviral treatment for primary genital HSV, as there is no evidence of benefit for treatment longer than this period [BASHH, 2014].
    • However, the WHO recommends that 10 days treatment should be provided, as follow-up visits may not be possible and symptoms of the first clinical episode may be prolonged [WHO, 2016].
  • CKS recommends using clinical judgement when determining the dose of antivirals and the duration of treatment.
Topical antivirals
  • Topical agents are less effective than oral agents, and combining oral and topical treatment is of no additional benefit over oral treatment alone [BASHH, 2014].
Choice of oral antiviral
  • There is no evidence of a difference in efficacy, tolerability, or toxicity between aciclovir, valaciclovir, or famciclovir in the management of primary genital herpes [Hollier 2013].
  • UK guidelines recommend aciclovir as first line treatment, while the NZHF recommends valaciclovir [NZHF, 2015].
    • CKS recommends that oral aciclovir should be prescribed first-line, as it is the least expensive option.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I treat someone with genital herpes simplex if they have HIV?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ideally, all people with HIV and suspected genital herpes should be referred to a specialist in genito-urinary medicine (GUM) for diagnosis, treatment, screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), counselling regarding risks to themselves and others, and follow up (especially if they are known to have a low CD4 count).
  • However, if referral is declined, people with HIV can be treated in primary care provided that the infection is uncomplicated and not severe.
    • Prescribe oral aciclovir 200–400 mg five times a day for 7–10 days. 
    • Alternatively, prescribe: 
      • Valaciclovir 500–1000 mg twice a day for 10 days.
      • Famciclovir 250–500 mg three times a day for 10 days. 
    • If new lesions are still forming after 3–5 days, seek specialist advice.
    • In people with advanced HIV, double the standard dose of antiviral should be considered.
  • If infection is severe, the person is systemically unwell, or complications are suspected, admit for treatment with intravenous aciclovir.
    • In the absence of antiretroviral treatment, primary genital herpes may be severe and prolonged with risk of progressive, multifocal, and coalescing mucocutaneous anogenital lesions.
    • Complications include fulminant hepatitis, pneumonia, neurological disease, and disseminated infection.
  • Advise all people about appropriate self care measures to help relieve symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Treatment of genital herpes simplex virus [WHO, 2016], and a systematic review Genital herpes: oral antiviral treatments [Hollier 2013], and the British National Formulary [BNF 73, 2017]. 

Dose of antiviral and duration of treatment
  • Be aware that dose recommendations for antivirals and the duration of treatment may differ between guidelines for treatment of genital herpes, the Summary of Product Characteristics and the British National Formulary (BNF). 
    • The WHO recommends the same dose of antivirals for primary genital HSV in people with HIV as for those without HIV. However, BASHH advises that the doses may need to be doubled [BASHH, 2014; WHO, 2016].
    • The BNF advises prescribing a dose of 500 mg famciclovir twice a day for 10 days [BNF 73, 2017]. 
  • CKS recommends using clinical judgement when determining the dose of antivirals and duration of treatment.
Choice of oral antiviral
  • There is no evidence to suggest that any one antiviral treatment is better than another for treating primary genital HSV in people with HIV [Hollier 2013].
  • UK guidelines recommend aciclovir as first line treatment, while the NZHF recommends valaciclovir [NZHF, 2015].
    • CKS recommends that oral aciclovir should be prescribed first-line, as it is the least expensive option. 
Referral in people with HIV
  • MEDFASH provides guidance on managing people with HIV in primary care and advises seeking help from an HIV specialist if a medical condition, such as herpes simplex, is severe or resistant to treatment [MEDFASH, 2016].
  • Five days treatment is adequate for most people, including those with HIV [BASHH, 2014].
  • BASHH recommends that if new lesions are still forming after 3–5 days of treatment, virus detection and typing should be repeated and susceptibility testing arranged in people with HIV [BASHH, 2014]. 
    • CKS considers that specialist referral is appropriate under these circumstances.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What self care measures are suitable for people with genital herpes simplex infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Self-care measures may be useful for some people. If appropriate, advise the person to:
    • Clean the affected area with plain or salt water to help prevent secondary infection and promote healing of lesions.
    • Apply vaseline or a topical anaesthetic (for example lidocaine 5%) to lesions to help with painful micturition, if required.
    • Increase fluid intake to produce dilute urine (which is less painful to void). Urinate in a bath or with water flowing over the area to reduce stinging.
    • Avoid wearing tight clothing, which may irritate lesions.
    • Take adequate pain relief.
    • Avoid sharing towels and flannels with household members (although it is very unlikely that the virus would survive on an object long enough to be passed on, it is sensible to take steps to prevent this).
  • Advise all people to abstain from sexual intercourse (including non-penetrative and oro-genital sex) until follow-up or until lesions have cleared.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Treatment of genital herpes simplex virus [WHO, 2016], the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015] and what CKS consider pragmatic advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give someone with herpes simplex?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Provide a written and verbal explanation of genital herpes simplex: the cause, signs and symptoms, transmission, complications, treatments and the prognosis, for example the Family Planning Association leaflet Genital herpes.
  • Explain that: 
    • Even with a negative swab result, they may still have genital herpes — the diagnosis can only be confirmed by a follow up test.
    • There is no cure for genital herpes at present.
      • On average, people have 4–5 attacks of genital herpes a year after the first symptomatic episode. 
      • However, symptoms improve (reduce in frequency and severity) with time and can be well controlled.
    • A first clinical episode may not necessarily indicate recent infection (or that a partner has been unfaithful). A subclinical infection could have been acquired years before, or a HSV 1 infection may have spread from elsewhere on the body (such as lips or fingers).
    • Transmission can occur when there are no symptoms (asymptomatic shedding), but the risk is higher when symptomatic. Advise the person:
      • To avoid sexual intercourse (including oro-genital sex) if lesions are present.
      • That when used consistently and correctly, male condoms may reduce the risk of transmission.
      • Transmission is still possible with close skin contact, or contact with infected secretions during foreplay.
      • To avoid sharing towels and flannels with household members, as although it is very unlikely that the virus will be transmitted this way, it is a sensible precaution.
  • Advise people who are concerned about transmitting genital herpes to long-term partners that their partner may already be infected even if they do not have symptoms, and that they should seek advice from a specialist in GUM for screening.
  • Explain that further support is available from the Herpes Viruses Association's helpline 0845 123 2305 (weekdays) or website if required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Treatment of genital herpes simplex virus [WHO, 2016], the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015].

Use of condoms
  • A 50% reduction in rate of transmission of HSV is seen in those using condoms for at least 25–60% of the time [BASHH, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer someone with genital herpes simplex?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ideally, all people with suspected genital herpes should be referred to a specialist in genito-urinary medicine for diagnosis, treatment, screening for sexually transmitted infections, counselling, and follow up.
  • It is essential to refer the following to the appropriate speciality:
    • Women who are pregnant. 
    • Immunocompromised individuals.
      • People with HIV can be treated in primary care provided that the infection is uncomplicated and not severe. However, prompt referral is indicated if there is no response to treatment (for example, if lesions are still forming after 3–5 days of treatment).
    • People with: 
      • Herpetic proctitis.
      • Severe local secondary infection.
      • Complications (for example urinary retention).
      • Systemic herpes infection (for example meningitis).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline for the management of anogenital herpes [BASHH, 2014], a joint guideline with the Royal College of General Practitioners Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Treatment of genital herpes simplex virus [WHO, 2016], the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015], and the Medical Foundation for HIV and Sexual Health (MEDFASH) guideline HIV in primary care: a practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [MEDFASH, 2016].

Referral in people with HIV
  • MEDFASH provides guidance on managing people with HIV in primary care and advises seeking help from an HIV specialist if a medical condition, such as herpes simplex, is severe or resistant to treatment [MEDFASH, 2016].
  • Five days treatment is adequate for most people, including those with HIV [BASHH, 2014].
  • BASHH recommends that if new lesions are still forming after 3–5 days of treatment, virus detection and typing should be repeated and susceptibility testing arranged in people with HIV [BASHH, 2014]. 
    • CKS considers that specialist referral is appropriate under these circumstances.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should a person with genital herpes simplex be followed up?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ideally, people should be followed up by a specialist in genito-urinary medicine (GUM). 
  • If this is not possible, or acceptable, follow up people unwilling to attend GUM, 5–7 days after the initial appointment to: 
    • Discuss swab results. 
    • Evaluate symptoms.
    • Complete a full sexually transmitted infection (STI) screen if appropriate.
    • Answer any questions the person may have.
    • Provide advice about recurrence and treatment options. 
  • Follow up once a year to:
    • Assess the need for episodic or suppressive therapy.
    • Discuss the importance of disease transmission prevention. 
    • Monitor psychological distress.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Herpes simplex infection [BMJ Best Practice, 2016] and the New Zealand Herpes Foundation (NZHF) Guidelines for the management of genital herpes in New Zealand [NZHF, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I suspect sexual abuse of a young person?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Although rare, consider the possibility of sexual abuse in any child or young person with genital herpes, particularly in the following circumstances:
    • The child is younger than 13 years of age, unless there is clear evidence of mother-to-child transmission during birth, or of blood contamination.
    • The young person is aged 13–15 years, unless there is clear evidence of mother-to-child transmission during birth, blood contamination, or that the sexually transmitted infection (STI) was acquired from consensual sexual activity with a peer.
    • The young person is aged 16–17 years and there is no clear evidence of blood contamination or that the STI was acquired from consensual sexual activity and there is a clear difference in power or mental capacity between the young person and their sexual partner, in particular when the relationship is incestuous or with a person in a position of trust (such as a teacher, sports coach, minister of religion) or there is concern that the young person is being exploited.
  • If child maltreatment is suspected, refer the young person to children's social care, following Local Safeguarding Children Board procedures.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Child maltreatment: when to suspect maltreatment in under 18s [NICE, 2009].
